comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Is the lady in the light coloured dress the "Miss Walsh" from your earlier shot?  They are very formal looking, probably well meaning and very charitable and a pack of auld biddies to work with.

comment._content: I don't know, have compared both faces, not convinced this young lady and Miss Walsh are one and the same... Miss Walsh, 16 June 1908: www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5838291769/in/photostream/

comment.author: 38524172@N08
comment._content:
I think she's not Miss Walsh, I believe that this photograph is one of a series in the Lawrence collection, The occasion was some sort of pageant or bazaar held in Tramore June 1909. Maybe the picture could be linked to the others in the series. 

The lady in white, second from the left was Margaret Mary Farrell, known as 'Bay'. She was baptized on October 19,1874 at Sacred Heart, Ferrybank, Waterford. She was one of  11 children born to Richard Farrell and Mary Monica (Downey), amongst whom was my Grandfather, Walter J. Farrell. Austin Farrell, (NLI Ref.: P_WP_3697) was another brother.

She was described by an Irish relative as being "high spirited" and had been known to go out "without her gloves." She moved to the United States and married Jeremiah Carew, who she knew from Waterford, at Fort Myer, Alexandria, Virginia in 1899. She died October 30, 1942 (aged 68) in  Bronx, New York. 

Brendan Grogan, Waterford. July 6th 2012.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38524172@N08] You have made me so happy, you have no idea! I have some photos of Miss Bay Farrell that I had been debating using over the last few days. I think "high spirited" would describe her. I will upload on Monday, and in the meantime, I'm going to replace this one with a higher res one. THANK YOU!!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
